title: Weekend Hot Topic, part 2: What’s your favourite indie game?
text:
Favourite indie game, Celeste, by a mile. Absolutely loved it despite not being that good at platforms, or particularly liking them. I really enjoyed Brothers: A Tale Of Two Sons as well, best £3 I’d spent in a long time, despite its short length I adored the time playing. Last Day Of June was another cracker I remember fondly this gen, along with Stardew Valley.

I tend to buy quite a lot of them, even have an indie game folder on my PlayStation 4, probably one in every three games I buy will be an indie; Little Nightmares, Suicide Guy 1 and 2, and Crossing Souls (or Accounting+ and The Mervils if counting VR) being the last ones I bought with my own pennies, once I saw them all at a reasonable price.

Saying that I’m quite sad Sony stopped giving them away on PS Plus, as I played so many little gems I’d never have played otherwise as they wouldn’t have stood out enough for me to make a purchase, which is a real shame. The Deadly Tower Of Monsters definitely being one I’d never have bought myself, but I ended up really enjoying it and getting the platinum for it. Portal Knights was great fun too, as was RiME, but sadly that kept crashing on me so I never got too far.

The saving grace I do have is that I’ve got 50+ indie games in my library just waiting for me to get round to playing them, and I will one day and likely find some new favourites. I’ll never stop buying indie games, although I know for sure I’d buy many more if I saw them boxed in shops. I’ll take a punt at under £10 or so digitally, anything over and I’m very wary considering they’re not adding to my physical collection nor can they be traded in.

It’s a shame the more ‘casual’ (I hate that term but I can’t think of anything else to describe those that stick to Fortnite, Call Of Duty 17, etc.) don’t give a chance to the games that don’t have a huge marketing budget, or that don’t have a massive development budget, but that’s the world we live in unfortunately. Even high quality, big budget games with enormous advertising campaigns bomb now so there’s little hope for the indies unless they’re exceptionally good and word of mouth pulls them in – much like Celeste, Hollow Knight, Undertale, etc. did.

Lost-Sock-

PS: As a sad note to the lad that wrote in about not buying games based on demos – I’ll add MediEvil to my own list. I was really looking forward to the remake but after the woeful, buggy, and boring demo I’ll not be bothering now, even at a budget price. Should have been left in nostalgia city.
description: GameCentral readers name their favourite ever indie games, from Celeste to Into The Breach.
